/--
Suppose $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ is continuous and for every $\alpha > 0$, $\lim_{n \to \infty} f(n\alpha) = 0$. Prove that $\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) = 0$.
-/
theorem putnam_1964_b3
(f : ℝ → ℝ)
(hf : Continuous f ∧ ∀ α > 0, Tendsto (fun n : ℕ ↦ f (n * α)) atTop (𝓝 0))

```lean4
theorem putnam_1964_b3
(f : ℝ → ℝ)
(hf : Continuous f ∧ ∀ α > 0, Tendsto (fun n : ℕ ↦ f (n * α)) atTop (𝓝 0))
: (Tendsto f atTop (𝓝 0)) := by
  have h₁ : ∀ α > 0, Tendsto (fun n : ℕ ↦ f (n * α)) atTop (𝓝 0) := fun α hα ↦ hf.2 α hα
  have h₂ : Tendsto f atTop (𝓝 0) := by
    have h₃ : Tendsto f atTop (𝓝 0) := by
      -- Use the fact that f is continuous and the given condition to show that f(x) tends to 0 as x tends to infinity.
      apply tendsto_of_locally_const
      intro x
      -- For any x, we can find a neighborhood around x where f is locally constant.
      obtain ⟨s, hs, hsf⟩ := Metric.nhds_basis_ball.exists_iff.mpr (by simpa using hf.1.continuousAt)
      use s, hs
      intro y hy
      -- Since f is continuous, it is locally constant on any open set.
      have h₄ : f y = f x := by
        have h₅ : y ∈ ball x (dist y x) := by simp [dist_comm]
        have h₆ : dist y x < dist y x := by simp_all [dist_comm]
        simp_all [dist_comm]
      simp_all
    exact h₃
  exact h₂
